div1.head: Jim to Mlle Marcelle Guerin May 16th ‘15
div1.p:
Your last letter, the one in which you tell me of the great amount of work at the hospital, and of your depression on account of the general situation; was received a couple of days ago while we were working night and day. I wanted to write to you immediately and to try and cheer you up, but until now I haven’t had a single minute. By Wednesday we are to have six new cars and as many drivers so maybe after
that I will have a little leisure.

Really you mustn’t worry. Things are going to come out perfectly all right. Of course you’ve read of the great success in the north. That’s the start. The seemingly perfect German machine will break, as all machines do. I can see signs of it here where the fighting is the most disheartening of any in the frontier long line. It is an awfully tedious and costly war and only
the wonderful French could stand up under it.
Its a most pathetic phase we see out here, and yet the soldiers just keep plugging along and bearing the hardships.

The other day a very young sous-lieutenant was killed. He was of a very prominent and influential family and his aged father, a one legged veteran of 1870, his mother and his sister were permitted to come out here to his funeral. One of our cars served as the hearse. The soldiers put the beautiful wild flowers
that are now in bloom all over the car. When the little procession reached the newly dug grave the mother broke down and was prostrate on the ground near the coffin. The venerable old father made an address. His voice was very weak and every so often, when he interspersed “Vie la France”, his words would choke and tears come to his eyes. The grave was under a most beautiful apple tree laden with blossoms and heavy with the pungent scent of a budding spring. Very
near was a battery of French artillery and every time it went into action the sister would clutch the arm of the officer standing with her and cling to him as the discharged shells tore overhead.

To turn to more amusing happenings I must tell you about the time we had of it yesterday, the hottest fire we’ve been under yet. To start out with we were here in our caserne going out by turn on our various calls. The
shells were going over us towards a point some six kilometers below. Finally we noticed their point of contact was moving up and suddenly one whistled in as if bound for a window we were standing near. We couldn’t help but instinctively dodge, and as they gradually came nearer and nearer we moved a bit down the hall towards the entrance. Just then the range changed and we got them on that side. One broke across
from us and as it did so we heard one of our cars come rushing down the street. The driver switched her off, made a running dive for shelter and just then another crashed down with a snarling explosion. The fellow was holding his order card out as he ran towards the door thru [sic] the small paved court yard and the whole thing reminded me strongly of the variety of dramatic warfare one sees on the stage.
All he needed was some flour on his shoulders to beat off as one does dust in the best 10-20-30 s.

Lovell and Curtin were still out and we wondered if they had been hit. They finally came in all right. Today, not fifteen minutes ago, a shell burst right in front of Curtin; and his car passed thru [sic] the smoke and fragments unharmed. I suppose they’ll begin on our immediate location a little later. During the shelling yesterday
a couple of us had a call for a poste de secours. On the way back I had the good fortune to see the French Artillery in action; the German shrapnel bursting overhead and many of the heavier shells bursting on the town below. As I went along I passed groups of soldiers kneeling behind fences taking in the action. Some were sports and had glasses. As I got into town and headed down a street I noticed it was strangely empty.
Ahead I heard a loud crash and saw dense clouds of smoke. Just as I got into line behind our cars another obus came snarling, sizzling along and crashed down just the other side of a wall next to me. I too made a graceful, but rapid, entrance into the caserne. No sooner had I entered than an erstwhile Paris buss came lumbering along, a fraction of a second later a shell banged down just in front of us at what
seemed the exact spot the car occupied, forty feet away from our door. We jumped out to look and saw the orderly and driver heading for us. We beckoned them in, and in they scurried. It was all just as if we were heading for shelter during a heavy rainstorm. I got the cap of the one that hit just in front and a handful of the shrapnel. Well it was a great time after that. Shell after shell came in and there was a
fearful racket.

Its up here, or at the other places at the front where the crowd of doctors that experiment around the Lycee Pasteur should come. Here is where the aid would be of the most value. The tent wouldn’t work here for it would be shelled off the map in about five seconds. I’d give anything to see some of those “swanking” orderlies, or auxiliaries of the Miss Mc Adoo, Miss Econimus brand escort the large tent
show out here. We’d get the tent erected at night on the ground of having a nice little surprise for the soldiers, then when day began to break, and the newly donated set of highly polished instruments had been neatly arranged in proximity to the operating table; when the immaculate orderlies were dolled out in their best at-the- front uniform, and the sweet young things in pumps and red crosses had assumed their finest come-to-me- poor-soldier-boy smile,
why we’d find a nice, convenient, good, old mud ditch to crawl into and watch the show. It certainly would be “some” show. I’d just love to watch the expressions the minute the first shell “eased” in.

Paul Rockwell has been given a very long leave by the Commission. There is a M. Thierrie up or down or out here, or what ever direction it is known as, that knows the Vicomte du Peloux very well and who received a letter
from him the other day in which he asked him to convey to me the news. It pleased me very much to be remembered that way. M. Thierrie, who speaks English perfectly keeps us supplied with English ^papers and New York Heralds. We can buy the Paris Matin out here.

We no longer live at our former base but stay now all the time at our advance point, which
is now our base, so to speak.

The gardens in this town are a delight. Never have I seen such exquisite bits as one finds in some of them. They would beat our Bois all to pieces Mademoiselle, and I’ve taken the liberty of wishing for you to walk thru [sic] them with me very, very often.

closer.salute: More anon, and my best to you.
